questions.text: A 56 year old male presents to the OPD with right eye ptosis. On examination of pupils, anisocoria is noted. On dimming the light of the room, anisocoria is increasing. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Horner's syndrome Anisocoria that increases in dim light indicates a sympathetic paresis of the dilator pupillae muscle as seen in Horner’s syndrome. It is characterized by the triad of miosis, ptosis and anhidrosis.

Highyeild:

ETIOLOGY Horner Syndrome can be congenital, acquired or purely hereditary(autosomal dominant). The interruption of the sympathetic fibres may occur Centrally - Between the hypothalamus and the fibres point of exit from the spinal cord C8 to T2. Peripherally - In the cervical sympathetic chain, at the superior cervical ganglion or along the carotid artery.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Multiple sclerosis is a demyelinating disorder with antibodies against the myelin sheath of nerve fibres. The peak onset is between 20-40 years of age and females are more commonly affected. It has a relapsing-remitting course . Patients with multiple sclerosis present with a variety of motor and sensory symptoms which may have asymmetrical involvement. Option: B. A brainstem lesion leading to oculomotor nerve palsy may lead to ptosis but there will be accompanying signs of ophthalmoplegia and signs of other cranial nerve palsies, motor and/or sensory deficits depending on the location of the lesion. Option: D. Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder seen mostly in females of age group 20-30 years which is characterized by generalized muscle weakness and rapidly developing fatigue of the muscles which increases as the day progresses and improves with rest. Ptosis is a symptom of MG, however, other relevant histories like the middle-aged female, and generalized weakness, are missing making the diagnosis of MG unlikely.

Extraedge:

The syndrome associated with Horner Syndrome is Pancoast Tumor Clinical Presentation - Shoulder and arm pain (90%) weakness of the muscles of the hand, Horner Syndrome. Most commonly caused by extension of apical lung tumors(Pancoast Tumor) at the superior thoracic inlet. Diagnosis - Contrast-enhanced axial CT -effective for identification of the lesion MRI for greater information about spatial relationships. Percutaneous needle biopsy for definitive histologic diagnosis

questions.text: A 64 year old male presents to the OPD with chronic cough and weight loss. He is a smoker for the last 40 years. On examination, ptosis is present and anisocoria is noted. What is the diagnosis of the case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Horner's syndrome This is most likely a case of Horner's syndrome secondary to a lung tumor at the bronchus as suggested by symptoms of chronic cough, weight loss and a history of chronic smoking. It explains the symptoms of ptosis . In Horner's syndrome, anisocoria increases in dim light due to sympathetic paresis of the iris dilator muscle.

Highyeild:

questions.text: A 46-year-old diabetic man presents to the Ophthalmology OPD for regular check-up. He has no symptoms. On examination, anisocoria is noted and the fundus is normal. Which of the following best describes anisocoria?

options.label: B
options.text: Very slow reaction to near reflex

questions.correct_answer: C. Unequal size of both pupils
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Unequal size of both pupils Anisocoria means the unequal size of pupils and can be seen in conditions like Horner's syndrome, oculomotor nerve palsy etc

Highyeild:

Differential Diagnosis : Horner Syndrome Adie pupil Argyll Robertson pupil Senile miosis Third nerve palsy Iris sphincter muscle paralysis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A, B. Absent light reflex and very slow and tonic reaction to near reflex is seen in Adie's tonic pupil which occurs more often in young women. Option: D. Light near dissociation is seen in Argyll Robertson's pupil which is caused by a lesion in the region of the tectum, usually in neurosyphilis.

Extraedge:

Peripherally - In the cervical sympathetic chain , at the superior cervical ganglion or along the carotid artery.

questions.text: A patient is referred from a physician to Ophthalmologist in view of ptosis. The patient is a known case of Horner's syndrome. Which pupillary abnormality is likely to be seen in the patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anisocoria Horner’s syndrome leads to sympathetic paresis of the dilator pupillae muscle causing anisocoria which increases in dim light.

Highyeild:

Differential Diagnosis : Horner Syndrome Adie pupil Argyll Robertson pupil Senile miosis Third nerve palsy Iris sphincter muscle paralysis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Tonic pupils are seen after denervation of the iris sphincter where the pupil does not respond well to light but to near stimulus. When the near stimulus is removed, the pupil dilates very slowly compared with the normal pupil. It is seen in Adie's syndrome, multiple system atrophy, segmental hypohidrosis, diabetes, and amyloidosis. Option: B. Argyll Robertson's pupil is light-near dissociation and occurs with neurosyphilis. Option: C. heterochromia is seen in Fuchs' heterochromic indocyclitis
